metadata.title: First imported case of 2019 novel coronavirus in Canada, presenting as mild pneumonia

summary: First imported case of 2019 novel coronavirus in Canada, presenting as mild pneumonia
Published Online February 13, 2020 https://doi.org/10.1016/ S0140-6736(20)30370-6
This online publication has been corrected.
The corrected version first appeared at thelancet.com on February 27, 2020
Emergency Medicine, Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre, Toronto, ON, Canada (G E Cleghorn); and Division of
Infectious Diseases, Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre, Toronto, ON, Canada (J A Leis)
Correspondence to: Dr Jerome A Leis, Divisions of General Internal Medicine and Infectious
Sunnybrook Health Sciences Centre, Toronto, ON 2075 , Canada jerome.leis@sunnybrook.ca
A 56-year-old man presented to the Emergency Department in Toronto, ON, Canada, with fever and non-productive cough, 1 day after returning from a 3-month visit to Wuhan, China.
A chest x-ray showed patchy bilateral, peribronchovascular, ill-defined opacities in all lung zones.

Considering the clinical presentation of viral pneumonia in a patient with the appropriate epidemiological risk, the patient was admitted as a probable case of 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) infection.
The public health authority was notified of the case on admission and it traced the contacts.
Coronavirus was detected in both mid-turbinate and throat swabs by PCR and confirmed as 2019-nCoV by sequencing.
1 day after admission to hospital, the patient developed mild haemoptysis and significant rhinorrhoea, but he remained otherwise well.
His intermittent fever lasted 5 days before fully resolving, and his platelet count normalised; he was discharged home and followed up by public health workers.
The authors believe this is the first confirmed case of 2019-nCoV in Canada.
The presentation with fever, cough, and bilateral pneumonia is typical of most cases described so far.
Only a minority of previously reported cases had thrombocytopenia—and this was a worrying feature in the patient.
Despite significant radio­ graphic abnormalities, the patient remained well and did not require intubation or supplemental oxygen— unlike many cases with similar x-ray findings reported so far.
This case highlights the milder spectrum of pneumonia caused by 2019-nCoV.
Contributors All authors were involved in the diagnosis, management, and care of the patient.
Written consent for publication was obtained from the patient.

Acknowledgments The authors would like to thank the nursing staff involved in this patient’s care, Infection Prevention and Control team members, as well as Anastasia Oikonomou, Manpreet Basuita, Shubhabrata Das, and Zachary Feilchenfeld
Figure: First case of 2019 novel coronavirus in Canada Chest x-ray shows bilateral, peribronchovascular, ill-defined opacities in all lung zones.
